awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation Research Project: Investigating the Integration of Mathematics into Biology by Reciprocal Course Content Exchange
awd_abstract_narration:
Fisk University and Tennessee State University are using the Intrusive Learning Community approach to test a theoretical model of factors that influence students to switch from STEM to non-STEM disciplines.  Researchers propose to use the Performance Pyramid to develop measures that examine the effectiveness of two interventions - a combined section of college algebra and general biology that infuses math into the science curriculum and a learning community to complete mathematics projects related to biology facilitated by undergraduate peer mentors called Peer Partnership Learning (PPL) leaders.  The objectives of the learning community are to promote interdisciplinary thinking and problem solving, decrease student mathematics anxiety, encourage students to pursue STEM coursework, and increase student self-efficacy and persistence in STEM. The PPL leaders in the learning community will form supportive networks and enhance learning and personal development of student participants. The proposed study is expected to provide important insights to guide STEM education and increase the pipeline of African American students who pursue STEM graduate education and careers.

Researchers will use a quasi-experimental non-equivalent control group design to test a multi-faceted hypothesis.  The hypothesis states that students who participate in the PPL leaders-focused learning community will demonstrate greater knowledge and skills in their STEM courses; that the conceptual elements of the performance pyramid can be quantified; that PPLs will endorse more performance pyramid support systems; that students will evaluate the learning community positively; and that participants will show higher show higher STEM retention and persistence.  Conversely, researchers postulate that the number of STEM students who switch to non-STEM disciplines will be reduced among participants in the small learning communities, and the level of math anxiety will significantly decrease upon completion of the integrated course.  The researchers will develop the course materials for intrusive learning and the survey to measure the support system in the Performance Pyramid model. They will use a combination of multivariate analyses of variance, Poisson regressions, structural equation modeling, Pearson's correlations, and descriptive statistics to analyze the research data.  They also intend to organize a faculty development workshop to encourage more STEM faculty to integrate learning communities in teaching.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
This project has created intrusive learning communities (LCs) to promote interdisciplinary thinking and problem solving, connect mathematics concepts with biology, reduce students' math anxiety, and increase historically marginalized students' participation in STEM.  LCs involved weekly sessions led by trained Peer Partnership Leaders (PPL) to reinforce course content and work on mathematics projects that connected biology course content. The Learning Communities consisted of PPLs and students who were enrolled in both General Biology I and College Algebra. The PPLs were students who had earned grades of B+ or higher in both General Biology and College Algebra. The research team identified seven core areas in General Biology and created seven interdisciplinary projects that align the mathematics concepts with the core areas in biology.  The PPLs guided the students in the learning community sessions to work on these seven interdisciplinary projects one hour each week outside of their class meeting time. In addition, the research team developed, tested, and refined the instruments to evaluate the outcomes of the learning community's intervention, which was based on the performance pyramid theoretical model of student supports.

The research team used a quasi-experimental design to compare LC students to separate General Biology I and College Algebra course control groups on respective measures of biology and algebra course knowledge, and an assessment of perceived performance pyramid supports. Group differences from a multivariate analysis of covariance on perceived performance pyramid supports were mostly statistically non-significant. Nonetheless, LC participation was associated with increased mathematics and biology course performance.

Intellectual Merit: In the initial development of the Student Support Needs Scale-Augmented (SSNS-A), it was found that the pilot sample data supported the addition of new items and removal of some original items to create more internally consistent subscales The following psychometric analyses extended the development study by finding adequate model fit via confirmatory factor analysis for a bifactor model and support its predictive and discriminative validity. 

Regarding the comparisons of the learning community to instruction as usual (IAU) groups, learning community students out performed IAU biology and college algebra students in respective course-related knowledge. However, no differences were found between groups for the SSNS-A overall score and subscales, as well as with self-ratings of math anxiety. Nonetheless, the learning community students reported significantly less absences from classes than the college algebra IAU group. In sum, the learning community intervention was related to greater course knowledge, and fewer missed college algebra courses, but did not affect student perceptions of receiving performance pyramid supports.

Additionally, the learning communities were extended to on-line based delivery due to the COVID-19 pandemic for two learning community cohorts. What was found was that the students remained in the learning communities. However, many students in the learning communities and IAU groups did not complete post-test outcomes measures due to new issues related to the pandemic.  

Broader Impacts: Through the support of this grants, the research team generated 4 journal publications, one pending manuscript and 21 conference presentations.  A total of 12 students were hired and trained to serve as PPL leaders to assist students in intrusive learning communities. Six students were accepted to the graduate programs in STEM, three students are pursuing medical degrees, and two students are rising seniors at Fisk University.  A total of 14 faculty members participated in the faculty development workshop led by Drs. Marsteller and Gross to learn the pedagogy on integration of interdisciplinary course projects in teaching in May 2021. 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/08/2022
Modified by: Qingxia Li
